awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: The Twenty-first (21st) International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (ICNAA); Brisbane, Australia; June 26-30, 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide student and early career travel funding support to attend the 21st International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols in Australia in 2023.  The primary broader impact of this grant would be to contribute to the scientific and professional development of young researchers working in various aspects of nucleation and aerosol research. Previous support of this type has supported awardees with high success and retention rates in these research fields.

This travel award aims to facilitate student and early career researcher participation in the 21st International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols, one of the premiere regular (4-year) international meetings concerning of the formation, physical, chemical and biological properties, transformations and cloud impacts of atmospheric particles. This meeting offers a unique opportunity for young scientists to share research results with, and network with, an international cross-section of experts in their fields. The meeting will be held in Brisbane, Australia from 26 June 2023 to 30 June 2023 at the Science and Engineering Centre of the Queensland University of Technology (QUT).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Participation in international conferences offers young scientists unmatched opportunities for sensing the pulse beat of scientific research, and evaluating the scientific merit of their own research, on a global scale. As well, there is a broader opportunity for developing their professional networks via face-to-face meeting with worldwide experts. The 21st International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (ICNAA) was held in Brisbane, Australia during June 26-30, 2023. This conference is typically held only once every four years but was delayed two years due to the COVID-19 pandemic. It connects research communities concerned with fundamental aspects of nucleation of all physical systems (how condensed phases first form), but with a heavy emphasis on atmospheric particles, and atmospheric aerosol scientists working from the scales of new particle formation from gases to the interactions of natural and pollution particles with clouds and at the climate scale. This proposal funded travel support for graduate students whose attendance to this conference would not have been possible without such support.

The existence of travel awards was advertised broadly via websites of the Committee on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (visible via the International Union of Geophysics and Geodesy), American Geophysical Union, American Association for Aerosol Research, and the American Meteorological Society, as well as via distributed emails. Awards were based on application forms reviewed by the International Advisory Committee of the 21st ICNAA. Five senior PhD students from four institutions were awarded airline costs, registration fees and housing stipends in various combinations to total approximately $4000 each. Other expenses were covered by the student's advisor's grants and/or supplemental awards from their institutions. High travel costs likely limited applications to this event in comparison to previous conferences.

Awardee presentations spanned the full range of meeting topic areas. All award recipients presented oral presentations. The ratio of oral presentations in the NSF award winners thus far exceeded the 60% oral distribution of all attendees (171 in total), showing the strong merit of the research presented by awardees who might not have otherwise had the opportunity to present their work.

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2023
Modified by: Paul J Demott
